SENT.plain: Objectives: Urinary incontinence arising in dementia lowers patient quality of life, predicts caregiver burden and nursing home placement, and predisposes to adding additional medicines that can further impair cognition, behavior, and function
An understanding of incontinence pharmacology can help the clinician predict and manage this adverse event in treating patients with dementia

Principal Observations:We encountered a patient with Alzheimer's disease and vascular dementia who developed urinary incontinence and parkinsonism when ziprasidone was added to the regimen for behavioral concerns.When he was switched to duloxetine, the incontinence and parkinsonism resolved whereas improvements in perseveration, irritability, paranoia, and agitation persisted

Conclusions:While a pharmacokinetic explanation is unlikely, the best evidence suggests that ziprasidone-mediated serotonin 5HT2 receptor blockade may explain the reversible incontinence, with an adrenergic alpha-1 receptor mechanism considered to be less likely
Patients on 5HT2 antagonist drugs, including atypical antipsychotics, should be observed for incontinence
In the event of incontinence developing in the context of these agents, duloxetine may represent a potential pharmacological alternative in some cases
Duloxetine may improve neuropsychiatric symptoms in dementia through its effects on serotonin, norepinephrine, and frontal dopamine
